issues.text: Whether in a Special Leave to Appeal under Article 136 of the Constitution, it is open to the appellants to re-agitate questions of fact and disturb the findings of fact arrived at by the courts below.

anchor.surface_text: In a Special Leave to Appeal under article 136, it is not open to the appellants to re-agitate questions of fact and ask the Court to disturb the findings of fact arrived at by the Courts below. Those findings must therefore be accepted as binding.

issues.text: Whether there was absence of mens rea required for the offence under section 392 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that there was absence of mens rea which it is necessary to establish under section 392. It is contended that the appellants honestly believed that they were taking the goods to a place within the State of Madhya Pradesh when they were caught in the mid-stream.

issues.text: Whether the appellants, having been previously tried and acquitted for an offence under section 7 of the Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act, 1946, could be tried again for offences under sections 332 and 392 of the Indian Penal Code in view of section 403 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: It was also contended that the appellants were already prosecuted for an offence under section 7 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act, 1946, for exporting the contraband goods and although they were convicted by the Magistrate they were acquitted on appeal by the Additional Sessions Judge, Sagar, on October 31, 1952.

issues.text: Whether the seizure of the prohibited goods by the Head Constable was legal, being within the territorial limits of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: He, however, held that the carts were caught at the other bank of the river Dhasan after they had crossed the Madhya Pradesh border but the seizure was nevertheless legal. This finding was sought to be made capital of in revision and it was contended that the seizure took place beyond the border of the State of Madhya Pradesh and was therefore illegal.

arguments.claim: The appellants were already prosecuted for an offence under section 7 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act, 1946, for exporting the contraband goods and acquitted on appeal, so they could not be tried again for the same offence or on the same facts for any other offence under section 403(1) of the Code of Criminal Procedure, or for which a different charge might have been made under section 236 or convicted under section 237.

anchor.surface_text: It was also contended that the appellants were already prosecuted for an offence under section 7 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act, 1946, for exporting the contraband goods and although they

court_response_anchor.surface_text: number be tried again for the same offence number on the same facts for any other offence for which a different charge from the one made against them

arguments.court_reasoning: Neither section 236 nor section 237 applies. Sub-section (2) of section 403 furnishes a complete answer: a person acquitted or convicted of any offence may be afterwards tried for any distinct offence for which a separate charge might have been made under section 235(1). The offences under sections 332 and 392 IPC are distinct from the offence under section 7 of the Essential Supplies Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Findings of fact by lower courts binding in special leave appeal under Article 136.

holdings.text: In a Special Leave to Appeal under article 136, it is not open to the appellants to re-agitate questions of fact and ask the Court to disturb the findings of fact arrived at by the Courts below. Those findings must therefore be accepted as binding.

anchor.surface_text: In a Special Leave to Appeal under article 136, it is not open to the appellants to re-agitate questions of fact and ask the Court to disturb the findings of fact arrived at by the Courts below. Those

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court practice in special leave petitions under Article 136 limits interference to questions of law, treating lower court factual findings as binding.

holdings.text: There was no absence of mens rea under section 392 IPC as the route chosen by appellants led to Uttar Pradesh, negativing honest belief of going to Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: This conclusion is, however, clearly negatived by the finding that the route which the appellants had chosen was number the route which led to Baraitha

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual finding on incorrect route chosen rebuts claim of honest belief, establishing knowledge required for mens rea in robbery.

holdings.text: Appellants could be tried under sections 332 and 392 IPC despite prior acquittal under section 7 Essential Supplies Act, as offences are distinct per section 403(2) CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section (2) of section 403 in our opinion furnishes a complete answer to the contention raised on behalf of the appellants. That sub-section reads 403 (2) --A person acquitted or convicted of any offence may be afterwards tried for any distinct offence for which a separate charge might have been made against him on the former trial under section 235, subsection (1).

holdings.reasoning_summary: IPC offences of hurt to public servant and robbery are distinct from export violation; s403(2) expressly permits trial for distinct offences triable separately under s235(1); ss236/237 inapplicable.

holdings.text: Seizure of prohibited goods by Head Constable was legal as carts were apprehended in mid-stream within Madhya Pradesh limits before crossing to Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the question whether the carts were within the limits of Madhya Pradesh State when they were actually apprehended there was evidence which was accepted that the carts were seized when they were in the mid-stream and the cart-men requested the Head Constable to let them take the carts on the other side of the river so that they may have their meals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted evidence shows seizure in mid-stream with temporary allowance to other bank for meals, then return, confirming jurisdiction within MP.
